page.title: 13Hop Growing & Marketing.
page.content: Hops are grown in Kent for use in beer making. The acreage has shrunk in recent years due to more efficient use and the production of more lagers, which require less hops. Some continental lagers made under licence stipulate the use of imported hops. 1985 has seen an increase in 'hop wilt' and this area is replacing the older aromatic varieties with the more bitter wilt resistant ones, which are in direct competition with continental hops. The aromatic oil of the hop has a soporific effect which is supposed to be of assistance to insomniacs. Hops are dried in kilns known as oast-houses and their circular buildings topped with a white cowl are a feature of Kentish countryside. Many are now being converted into houses but retain their outward appearance.
